'''''Black Lightning''''' is an American [[superhero fiction|superhero]] television series developed by [[Salim Akil]], airing on [[The CW]]. It is based on the [[DC Comics]] [[Black Lightning|character of the same name]], created by [[Tony Isabella]] and [[Trevor Von Eeden]]. It stars [[Cress Williams]] as the titular character alongside [[China Anne McClain]], [[Nafessa Williams]], [[Christine Adams (actress)|Christine Adams]], [[Krondon|Marvin Jones III]], [[Damon Gupton]], and [[James Remar]]. The series sees the retired Black Lightning return to the hero life and its effects on his family life.
Development on the series began in September 2016 when [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] ordered a pilot production commitment for ''Black Lightning''. In February 2017, Fox passed on the series, with it being picked up by The CW with a new script for the pilot. The CW officially ordered the series in May 2017. The [[Black Lightning (season 1)|first season]] premiered on January 16, 2018, for a 13-episode run. On April 2, 2018, The CW renewed the show for a [[Black Lightning (season 2)|second season]], which premiered on October 9, 2018.
==Premise== High school principal Jefferson Pierce, who retired from his superhero persona [[Black Lightning]] nine years ago after seeing the effects it had on his family, is forced to become a [[vigilante]] again when the rise of the local gang called the 100 leads to increased crime and corruption in his community of Freeland.<ref name="NewPremise">{{cite web|url=http://ew.com/tv/2017/05/18/cw-superheroes-crossover-black-lightning-flash-arrow-legends-tomorrow/|title=The CW's Black Lightning not part of Arrowverse, crossover unlikely|last=Abrams|first=Natalie|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=May 18, 2017|accessdate=May 22, 2017}}</ref>
In season two, as Black Lightning continues his feud with the 100's leader [[Tobias Whale]], he and his family deal with the arising anti-superhuman bigotry within their community after its metahuman members' existences are exposed.
==Cast and characters== {{main|List of Black Lightning characters}}
* [[Cress Williams]] as [[Black Lightning|Jefferson Pierce / Black Lightning]]: A retired [[superhero]] with the ability to harness and manipulate electricity who works as a principal at [[James A. Garfield|Garfield High School]]. He returns to fighting crime after his daughters are kidnapped by a local gang.<ref name="WilliamsCast">{{cite web|url=http://tvline.com/2017/02/24/black-lightning-cast-cress-williams-the-cw-dc-comics-pilot/|title=Black Lightning: Cress Williams to Star in The CW's Latest DC Comics Pilot|last=Swift|first=Andy|publisher=[[TVLine]]|date=February 24, 2017|accessdate=February 24, 2017}}</ref><ref name="NewPremise" /> Kaden Washington Lewis portrays teenage Jefferson Pierce. * [[China Anne McClain]] as [[Lightning (DC Comics)|Jennifer Pierce<!--Do NOT add Jennifer's code name here until it is confirmed she will go by it!-->]]: Jefferson's younger daughter, who is "an independent, outspoken scholar-athlete with a wild streak of her own",<ref name="WilliamsMcClain">{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/03/black-lightning-daughters-cast-nafessa-williams-china-anne-mcclain-cw-pilot-1202034638/|title='Black Lightning' CW Pilot: Nafessa Williams, China Anne McClain Cast|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=March 2, 2017|accessdate=May 10, 2017}}</ref> who also possesses powers where her cells start generating energy; her electric power is orange unlike her father's which is blue.<ref name="Thunder" /><!-- Per the source: "EP Salim Akil previously told EW that Jefferson won’t be pleased when he finds out about his daughters’ powers.... 'That’s how Jefferson will react to seeing his daughters get their powers.'" Note that 'daughter' is plural both times.--> * [[Nafessa Williams]] as [[Thunder (comics)|Anissa Pierce / Thunder]]: Jefferson's elder daughter who is in medical school and teaches part-time at Jefferson's school.<ref name="WilliamsMcClain"/> Anissa is a [[metahuman]] like her father, having an ability to manipulate her density with her breathing and emotions, endowing herself with superhuman strength and durability. She can also create powerful shockwaves against her opponents with this power during combat. In addition, she has an accelerated healing factor. She eventually fights crime as Thunder,<ref name="Thunder">{{cite web|url=http://ew.com/tv/2018/01/04/black-lightning-first-look-thunder/|title=Black Lightning unveils first look at Thunder|last=Agard|first=Chancellor|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=January 4, 2018|accessdate=January 9, 2018}}</ref> and later becomes her father's protégée and partner. Describing her character as a positive role model, Williams said "I'm just really grateful to tell the story for young [[lesbian]]s — and black lesbians in particular ... My hope is that when you watch Anissa, a young lesbian is inspired to walk boldly as who she is and to love herself and to love herself exactly how she looks."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Agard|first1=Chancellor|title=Black Lightning breakout talks playing a black lesbian superhero|url=http://ew.com/tv/2018/01/30/black-lightning-anissa-nafessa-williams-interview/|website=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=January 30, 2018|accessdate=7 February 2018}}</ref> * [[Christine Adams (actress)|Christine Adams]] as Lynn Stewart: A [[neuroscientist]] at Bowman College and Jefferson's ex-wife.<ref name="Adams">{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/03/black-lightning-christine-adams-cast-jeffersons-ex-wife-lynn-the-cw-pilot-1202041455/|title='Black Lightning': Christine Adams Cast As Jefferson's Ex-Wife|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=March 10, 2017|accessdate=May 10, 2017}}</ref> * [[Krondon|Marvin "Krondon" Jones III]] as [[Tobias Whale]]: A former politician who rose through the ranks of local government through corruption but was brought down by Jefferson's father, Alvin. After killing Alvin, Tobias was exiled and became the leader of [[100 (DC Comics)|the 100]].<ref name="JonesCast" /> Despite being Black Lightning's chief adversary and wanting to kill him, Whale becomes involved with the A.S.A.'s efforts to capture and study him. * [[Damon Gupton]] as [[Inspector Henderson|Bill Henderson]]: A veteran detective inspector with the police who becomes an unlikely ally to Jefferson, despite his role in the community. After exposing the dirty Deputy Chief, Cayman, he is appointed to replace him.<ref name="SDCCCastings" /> Henderson eventually learns that Jefferson is Black Lightning, fracturing their relationship.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ign.com/articles/2018/10/10/black-lightning-season-2-jefferson-henderson-secret-identity-fired|title=Black Lightning Season 2: Cress Williams Talks Premiere Twist And Anissa's Dangerous Choice|last=Prudom|first=Laura|publisher=[[IGN]]|date=October 9, 2018|accessdate=October 11, 2018}}</ref> * [[James Remar]] as [[Peter Gambi]]: Jefferson's oldest friend who became a father figure and mentor to him and works as his "tailor" while having connections with Lady Eve. His real name is Peter Esposito and was a former member of the [[List of government agencies in DC Comics#A.S.A.|A.S.A.]] until he turned against the organization and gave information to Alvin Pierce, resulting in his murder.<ref name="SDCCCastings" /> * [[Jordan Calloway]] as Khalil Payne / [[Black Lightning#Antagonists|Painkiller]] (season 2; recurring, season 1): A track star at Garfield High and Jennifer's ex-boyfriend. After a bullet from Syonide's gun paralyzes him from the waist down, he becomes involved with Tobias Whale where he undergoes an experimental treatment done by the A.S.A. involving a spinal implant that gives him enhanced abilities, becomes a [[cyborg]] in the process. Tobias Whale is the one who names Khalil's new form of Painkiller.<ref>http://comicbook.com/dc/2018/01/24/black-lightnings-china-anne-mcclain-talks-her-characters-relatio/</ref>

==Production== ===Development=== In September 2016, after being in various stages of development, [[Warner Bros. Television]] began pitching ''Black Lightning'' to networks.<ref>{{cite web|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|url=http://deadline.com/2016/09/black-lightning-dc-superhero-series-greg-berlanti-mara-brock-akil-salim-akil-1201811892/|title=‘Black Lightning’ DC Superhero Series In Works From Greg Berlanti, Mara Brock Akil & Salim Akil|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=September 1, 2016|accessdate=May 11, 2017}}</ref> The project was being developed by [[Mara Brock Akil]] and her husband, Salim Akil. They were partnered with [[Greg Berlanti]], who was behind several DC Comics properties for the studio, eventually landing at [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] with a pilot production commitment.<ref>{{cite web|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|url=http://deadline.com/2016/09/black-lightning-fox-dc-superhero-drama-series-greg-berlanti-mara-brock-salim-akil-1201815368/|title=Fox Nabs ‘Black Lightning’ DC Superhero Drama With Pilot Production Commitment|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=September 8, 2016|accessdate=May 11, 2017}}</ref> In February 2017, Fox opted not to go forward with the project, deciding that it was "not a good fit into its already crowded genre drama space".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/02/black-lightning-dc-comic-drama-move-the-cw-greg-berlanti-1201901139/|title=‘Black Lightning’ Drama Eyes Move To the CW To Join Greg Berlanti Comic Lineup|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=February 2, 2017|accessdate=May 11, 2017}}</ref> Warner Bros. Television presented the project to other networks, with [[The CW]] officially ordering a pilot for ''Black Lightning''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/02/black-lightning-dc-drama-the-cw-pilot-order-greg-berlanti-mara-brock-akil-salim-1201901901/|title=‘Black Lightning’ DC Drama From Greg Berlanti & ‘The Game’ Duo Gets The CW Pilot Order|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=February 3, 2017|accessdate=May 11, 2017}}</ref> The CW also opted to discard the original pilot script, as it had been written for Fox, and shoot a short presentation instead.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/04/pilots-2017-early-buzz-primetime-broadcast-networks-1202063678/|title=PILOTS 2017: Very, Very Early Buzz Edition|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=April 12, 2017|accessdate=May 11, 2017}}</ref> The CW officially ordered ''Black Lightning'' to series on May 10, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/05/black-lightning-life-sentence-series-the-cw-1202089253/|title='Black Lightning' & Lucy Hale's 'Life Sentence' Picked Up To Series By The CW|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=May 10, 2017|accessdate=May 11, 2017}}</ref>
On April 2, 2018, The CW renewed the show for a second season, which premiered on October 9, 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/riverdale-flash-supernatural-10-cw-renewals-1098997|title='Riverdale,' 'Flash,' 'Supernatural' Among 10 CW Renewals|last=Goldberg|first=Leslie|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=April 2, 2018|accessdate=April 2, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://tvline.com/2018/06/20/cw-premiere-dates-fall-2018-flash-charmed-riverdale/|title=The CW Sets Fall Premiere Dates, Including New 'Super' Sunday|last=Swift|first=Andy|date=June 20, 2018|work=TVLine|access-date=June 20, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref>
===Writing=== Salim Akil stated that ''Black Lightning'' would not follow the [[villain of the week]] format or be a [[Procedural (genre)|procedural]], because he wanted to "explore the characters, even the villains".<ref name=":0" />
===Casting=== In late February 2017, [[Cress Williams]] was cast as Jefferson Pierce / Black Lightning,<ref name="WilliamsCast" /> followed a month later by the casting of [[China Anne McClain]] and [[Nafessa Williams]] as his daughters, [[Lightning (DC Comics)|Jennifer Pierce]] and [[Thunder (comics)|Anissa Pierce]], respectively,<ref name="WilliamsMcClain" /> and [[Christine Adams (actress)|Christine Adams]] was cast as Lynn Pierce, Jefferson's ex-wife.<ref name="Adams" /> At the 2017 [[San Diego Comic-Con International]], it was announced that [[James Remar]] and [[Damon Gupton]] had joined the cast as Pierce's friend Peter Gambi and detective inspector [[Inspector Henderson|Henderson]], respectively.<ref name="SDCCCastings">{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/07/black-lightning-casts-james-remar-damon-gupton-series-regulars-comic-con-1202133950/|title=‘Black Lightning’ Casts James Remar & Damon Gupton As Series Regulars, Watch Trailer – Comic-Con|last=Petski|first=Denise|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=July 22, 2017|accessdate=July 23, 2017}}</ref> The following month, [[Krondon|Marvin "Krondon" Jones III]] of the hip hop group [[Strong Arm Steady]] was cast as [[Tobias Whale]].<ref name="JonesCast">{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/08/marvin-krondon-jones-iii-black-lightning-tobias-whale-warner-brothers-tv-sam-akil-mara-brock-akil-the-cw-1202146162/|title=‘Black Lightning’ Adds Marvin "Krondon" Jones III As Villain Tobias Whale|last=Ramos|first=Dino-Ray|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=August 10, 2017|accessdate=August 10, 2017}}</ref>
At the end of September 2017, Kyanna Simone Simpson was cast as the recurring role Kiesha.<ref name="SimpsonCast">{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/09/black-lightning-kyanna-simone-simpson-recur-cw-series-1202176356/|title=‘Black Lightning’: Kyanna Simone Simpson Set To Recur In the CW Series|last=Petski|first=Denise|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=September 26, 2017|accessdate=September 27, 2017}}</ref> The following month, [[Edwina Findley]] joined the cast as Tori Whale,<ref name="Findley">{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/10/black-lightning-edwina-findley-recur-the-cw-series-1202187033/|title='Black Lightning': Edwina Findley Set To Recur In the CW Series|last=Petski|first=Denise|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=October 12, 2017|accessdate=November 1, 2017}}</ref> while Chantal Thuy was cast as [[Grace Choi]].<ref name="Thuy">{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2017/tv/news/black-lightning-chantal-thuy-dc-comics-grace-choi-exclusive-1202602693/|title='Black Lightning' Casts Chantal Thuy as DC Comics' Grace Choi (Exclusive)|last=Bryant|first=Jacob|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=October 30, 2017|accessdate=October 30, 2017}}</ref> In January 2018, it was revealed that Skye Marshall had been cast as Mrs. Fowdy.<ref name="Marshall">{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2018/01/black-lightning-skye-marshall-recur-the-cw-series-1202244242/|title='Black Lightning': Skye Marshall To Recur On the CW Series|last=Petski|first=Denise|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=January 16, 2018}}</ref>
===Design=== Black Lightning's costume was designed by Laura Jean Shannon.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2017/03/29/first-look-at-black-lightning-from-the-cws-new-dc-comics-pilot|title=First Look At Black Lightning From The CW's New DC Comics Pilot|last=Goldman|first=Eric|publisher=[[IGN]]|date=March 29, 2017|accessdate=March 30, 2017}}</ref>
===Filming=== Filming for the series takes place in [[Atlanta]].<ref name="NewPremise" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/03/pilot-locations-2017-new-york-vancouver-atlanta-los-angeles-toronto-chicago-1202035016/|title=Pilot Locations 2017: NY, Vancouver & Atlanta Tick Up; LA, Toronto, Chicago Slip|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=March 7, 2017|accessdate=May 11, 2017}}</ref> Filming for the first season began August 14, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://screenrant.com/black-lightning-tv-show-filming-august/amp|title=Black Lightning Starts Filming In August|date=July 3, 2017}}</ref> Filming for the second season began June 28, 2018<ref>{{cite web|url=https://comicbook.com/dc/2018/06/28/black-lightning-season-2-production-begins|title='Black Lightning' Season 2 Has Begun Production|website=comicbook.com|date=June 28, 2017}}</ref>
===Music=== [[Kurt Farquhar]] composes the soundtrack for the series while Godholly provides original music for the series. These tracks include "Black Lightning", "Power", "Green Light", "Welcome to Freeland", "Can't Go" and "Thunder".{{citation needed|date=April 2018}}

===Broadcast=== ''Black Lightning'' began airing on The CW on January 16, 2018,<ref name="PremiereDate">{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/11/black-lightning-gets-premiere-date-post-flash-time-slot-by-the-cw-1202209913/|title='Black Lightning' Gets Premiere Date, Post-'Flash' Time Slot By the CW|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=November 16, 2017|accessdate=November 16, 2017}}</ref> and ran for 13 episodes.<ref name="EpisodeCount">{{cite tweet|user=SydneyBucksbaum|author=Sydney Bucksbaum|number=892791471840968704|title=#TheOriginals final season and #BlackLightning will also be 13 episodes each this year. #TCA17|date=August 2, 2017|accessdate=August 2, 2017}}</ref> [[Netflix]] airs new episodes of Black Lightning weekly outside of the United States. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.whats-on-netflix.com/news/black-lightning-season-2-netflix-release-schedule/|title=Black Lightning Season 2 Netflix Release Schedule|date=October 2, 2018|website=What's on Netflix|}}</ref>
===Home media=== The first season was released on [[Blu-ray]] and [[DVD]] in [[DVD region code#Region codes and countries|Region 1]] on June 26, 2018.<ref name="S1HomeMedia">{{cite web |title=Black Lightning: Season 1 |url=https://www.amazon.com/Black-Lightning-China-Anne-McClain/dp/B07CDVZ479 |website=Amazon}}</ref>
==Reception== ===Critical response=== On [[review aggregator]] website [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the first season has received a 96% approval rating, with an average rating of 8.35/10, based on 48 reviews.<ref name="RT">{{cite web|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/black_lightning/s01 |title=Black Lightning: Season 1 (2018) |work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |publisher=[[Fandango Media]] |accessdate=April 18, 2018}}</ref> The website's critical consensus reads, "''Black Lightning'' doesn't reinvent superhero TV, but it does give the genre a necessary jolt with real-world plots, scary new villains, and a star-making performance from Cress Williams."<ref name="RT" /> [[Metacritic]], which uses a weighted average, assigned a score of 79 out of 100 based on 25 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews".<ref name="MC">{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/tv/black-lightning |title=Black Lightning: Season 1 |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |work=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=February 7, 2018}}</ref>
Daniel Fienberg, in a review for ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'', praised the series for being "smart and relevant and full of an attitude that's all its own."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/black-lightning-review-1074361|title='Black Lightning': TV Review|last=Fienberg|first=Daniel|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=January 15, 2018|accessdate=January 16, 2018}}</ref> Nafessa Williams's portrayal of Thunder has received praise for being the first representation of a black [[lesbian]] superhero on television.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Massabrook|first1=Nicole|title=‘Black Lightning’ Star Nafessa Williams Hopes Her Lesbian Superhero Inspires Viewers|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/black-lightning-star-nafessa-williams-hopes-her-lesbian-superhero-inspires-viewers-2644239|website=[[International Business Times]]|date=January 23, 2018|accessdate=7 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Avery|first1=Dan|title="Black Lightning" Is Bringing One Of The Few Lesbian Superheroes Of Color To Television|url=http://www.newnownext.com/black-lightning-lesbian-thunder/01/2018/|website=[[NewNowNext]]|date=January 16, 2018|accessdate=7 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Scott|first1=Sydney|title='Black Lightning' Star Nafessa Williams On Her History-Making Role And Repping Philly|url=https://www.essence.com/entertainment/black-lightning-nafessa-williams-interview|website=[[Essence (magazine)|Essence]]|date=January 16, 2018|accessdate=7 February 2018}}</ref>
===Accolades=== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |- style="background:#ccc; text-align:center;" ! scope="col"| Year ! scope="col"| Award ! scope="col"| Category ! scope="col"| Recipient(s) and nominee(s) ! scope="col"| Result ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | {{Abbr|Ref.|Reference}} |- | rowspan="4"|2018 | [[44th People's Choice Awards|People's Choice Awards]] | The Sci-Fi/Fantasy Show of 2018 | ''Black Lightning'' | {{pending}} | style="text-align:center;"|<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.eonline.com/shows/peoples_choice_awards/news/963752/2018-people-s-choice-awards-complete-list-of-nominations|title=2018 People's Choice Awards: Complete List of Nominations|publisher=E! News|date=September 5, 2018|accessdate=September 5, 2018}}</ref> |- | [[44th Saturn Awards|Saturn Awards]] | [[Saturn Award for Best Superhero Adaptation Television Series|Best Superhero Television Series]] | ''Black Lightning'' | {{nom}} | style="text-align:center;"| <ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2018/film/news/saturn-awards-nominations-2018-black-panther-walking-dead-1202727752/|title=‘Black Panther,’ ‘Walking Dead’ Rule Saturn Awards Nominations|last=McNary|first=Dave|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=March 15, 2018|accessdate=March 15, 2018|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6xwc1azco?url=http://variety.com/2018/film/news/saturn-awards-nominations-2018-black-panther-walking-dead-1202727752/|archivedate=March 15, 2018|deadurl=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> |- | rowspan="2"|[[2018 Teen Choice Awards|Teen Choice Awards]] | [[Teen Choice Award for Choice Breakout Series|Choice Breakout TV Show]] | ''Black Lightning'' | {{nom}} | style="text-align:center;" rowspan=2| <ref>{{cite web |last1=Douglas |first1=Esme |title=Teen Choice Awards 2018: See the full list of winners |url=https://ew.com/awards/2018/08/12/teen-choice-awards-winners-list/ |website=[[Entertainment Weekly|EW]] |accessdate=August 13, 2018 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180813151232/https://ew.com/awards/2018/08/12/teen-choice-awards-winners-list/ |archivedate=August 13, 2018}}</ref> |- | Choice Breakout TV Star | [[Nafessa Williams]] | {{nom}} |}
==Connection to the Arrowverse== {{further|Arrowverse}}
Despite airing on The CW and being created by Berlanti, Mark Pedowitz, president of The CW said in May 2017 that the series "at this time, is not part of the [[Arrowverse]]. It is a separate situation."<ref name="NewPremise" /> Berlanti had previously stated when the series was in development at Fox that it would not crossover with his other DC Comics television properties on The CW nor would it exist in the Arrowverse.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbr.com/foxs-black-lightning-show-wont-cross-over-with-the-arrowverse/|title=Fox's Black Lightning Show Won't Cross Over With The Arrowverse|last=Gerding|first=Stephen|publisher=Comic Book Resources|date=January 9, 2017|accessdate=February 3, 2017}}</ref> However, Akil later stated that they were not ruling out eventual crossovers.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/black-lightning-tv-show-spoilers-what-eps-revealed-atx-2550641|title=‘Black Lightning’ TV Show Spoilers: What The EPs Revealed At ATX|last=Massabrook|first=Nicole|publisher=International Business Times|date=June 11, 2017|accessdate=July 17, 2017}}</ref> In August 2017, Pedowitz added, "If [the showrunners] wish to bring it in, that is their call. We had a long discussion with the studio, Mara, Salim, and myself. We were fine with them making it separate from the Arrowverse, they have a different point of view. If they end up wanting to go that way, that will be their decision."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2017/08/02/this-arrowverse-crossover-will-fully-take-place-across-every-show-from-supergirl-to-legends-of-tomorrow|title=This Arrowverse Crossover Will Fully Take Place Across Every Show From Supergirl To Legends of Tomorrow|last=Schwartz|first=Terri|publisher=[[IGN]]|date=August 2, 2017|accessdate=August 7, 2017|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6sXpqo5uc|archivedate=August 7, 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref> Salim Akil noted references in the first season to the Arrowverse heroes Vixen and Supergirl were a "fun" way "to tease the fans". He also further reiterated that the series existed on a separate Earth from the other Arrowverse series (like Earth-1 from ''[[The Flash (2014 TV series)|The Flash]]'', ''[[Arrow (TV series)|Arrow]]'', and ''[[Legends of Tomorrow]]'' and Earth-38 from ''[[Supergirl (TV series)|Supergirl]]'') and was hopeful that any future crossover would involve the heroes of the other series visiting the Earth that is associated with ''Black Lightning''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ew.com/tv/2018/04/16/black-lightning-boss-addresses-arrowverse-references/|title=Black Lightning boss addresses those Arrowverse references|last=Agard|first=Chancellor|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=April 16, 2018|accessdate=April 17, 2018}}</ref>

{{Cleanup|reason=The grammar is of subpar quality|date=September 2012}} [[Image:Stari Most22.jpg|right|thumb|260 px| [[Stari Most]] (The Old Bridge) in [[Mostar]], 1557. [[UNESCO World Heritage Site]]]] {{Culture of Bosnia and Herzegovina}} '''Bosnia and Herzegovina art''' is art from the region of [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]], and its constituent ethno-religious groups ([[Bosniaks]], [[Serbs]] and [[Croats]]) from [[prehistory|prehistoric]] times to today.
==Ancient heritage==
=== Prehistory=== [[Image:Badanj.jpg|thumb|left|"Horse attacked by arrows", engraving in cave Badanj near [[Stolac]], c. 14000 BC.]]In the boundaries of today’s [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] there have been many layers of prehistory cultures and their creation and disappearance is linked to migrations of unidentified ethnic groups.
[[Paleolithic]] in Bosnia and Herzegovina is marked with the oldest monument of Paleolithic in southeastern Europe - [[engraving]]s in a cave named ''Badanj'' near [[Stolac]] in [[Herzegovina]]. Most famous being the ''Horse attacked by arrows'', preserved in fragments and dated around 14500-12000 B.C.<ref>Ivan Lovrenović 2001. Bosnia: a cultural history. New York. New York University Press. p. 13</ref>
During the time when [[Neolithic]] and [[Copper]] cultures were starting to appear, in Bosnia and Herzegovina began interesting mixture of [[Mediterranean]] cultures and those of [[Panonian]] cultures. Herzegovina was under the influence of impresso ceramics from western Mediterranean as seen in ''Green Cave'' near [[Mostar]], ''Čairi'' near [[Stolac]], ''Lisičići'' near [[Konjic]] and ''Peć Mlini'' near [[Grude]]. People used to live in caves or simple settlements on hilltops. In the upper mainstream of Bosna river and northeast parts of Bosnia (''Obra I'' near [[Kakanj]]) people used to live in wooden houses built along rivers. In that culture we can see influences from Adriatic cultures on south and ''Starčević culture'' on northeast. Original expressions of that culture are ceramic pots on four legs, so called – [[Rhyton]]. We can find the also in ''Danilo culture'' on the Croatian coast. Thanks to these pieces, Kakanj culture is considered a part of wide circle of Neolithic nations that followed a ''cult of life force'' (from northern [[Italy]], [[Dalmatia]] and [[Epirus]] to [[Aegean Sea|Aegean]]). [[Butmir Culture]] near [[Sarajevo]] is distinctive with fine glazed ceramics with miscellaneous geometrical decorations (often spirals).<ref>W. Radymský / M. Hoernes, Die neolithische Station von Butmir bei Sarajevo in Bosnien. Ausgrabungen im Jahre 1893 (Wien 1895).</ref><ref>Z. Kujundzič-Vejzagič / J. Müller / K. Rassmann / T. Schüler, Okolište – Grabung und Geomagnetik eines zentralbosnischen Tells aus der ersten Hälfte des 5. vorchristlichen Jahrtausends. In: B. Hänsel (Hrsg.), Parerga Praehistorica: Jubiläumsschrift zur Prähistorischen Archäologie. 15 Jahre UPA. Universitätsforsch. Prähist. Arch. 100 (Bonn 2004) 69–81.</ref> Figures from Butmir are unique sculptures modeled with hand; heads are almost like portraits with emphasized parts of body.
[[Image:Daorson.jpg|thumb|260 px|right|Monumental city walls of [[Daorson]] near Stolac, 4th century BC.]][[Bronze Age]] settlements in Herzegovina were built like [[citadel]]s (natively called - ''gradina''), and in Bosnia we have necropolises with stone [[tumuli]]. During that time, bronze arms, decorated plates, flat necklaces and fibulas were decorated with specific geometrical style of engraved ornaments. From 7th century BC bronze is replaced by iron, and only jewelry and art objects were still made out of bronze. Bronze culture of [[Illyrians]], ethnic group with distinct culture and art form started to organize itself on today’s Croatia, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina. Different Illyrian tribes, under the influence of [[Halstat]] cultures from north, formed original regional centers. With the notable exception of [[Pod, Bosnia and Herzegovina|Pod]] near [[Bugojno]] in the upper valley of the [[Vrbas (river)|Vrbas River]], nothing is known of their settlements. In eastern Bosnia in the cemeteries of ''Belotić'' and ''Bela Crkva'', the rites of inhumation and [[cremation]] are attested, with skeletons in stone [[cists]] and cremations in [[urns]]. Metal implements appear here side-by-side with stone implements. Most of the remains belong to the fully developed Middle Bronze Age. Very important role in their life was ''the cult of the dead'', which is seen in their careful burials and burial ceremonies, as well as richness of the burial sites. In northern parts there was long tradition of [[cremation]] and burial in shallow graves, while in the south the dead were buried in large stone, or earth tumuli (natively called – ''gromile'') that in Herzegovina were reaching monumental sizes, more than 50 m wide and 5 m high. ''Japodian'' tribes (found around [[Bihać]]) have had affinity to decoration (heavy, oversized necklaces out of yellow, blue or white glass paste, and large bronze fibulas, as well as spiral bracelets, diadems and helmets out of bronze foil.
In 4th century BC first outbreak of [[Celts]] is recorded. They brought the technique of the pottery wheel, new types of fibulas and different bronze and iron belts. They only passed on their way to Greece, so their influence in Bosnia and Herzegovina is negligible.
===Antiquity=== [[Image:7th century fibula.jpg|thumb|left|80px|Silver fibula cross from 7th century found on [[Buško Blato]] lake in Herzegovina.]] [[Image:Drinovci-starokršćanska krstionica.jpg|thumb|right|Stone baptistery from ''Drinovci'' near [[Grude]], 4th century.]] In the [[Neretva Delta]] in the south there was important [[Hellenistic]] influence of Illyrian tribe [[Daors]]. Their capital was [[Daorson]] in ''Ošanići'' near [[Stolac]];<ref>[http://www.stolac.org/4images/categories.php?cat_id=10 Images of antiquities from Daorson] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081207182903/http://www.stolac.org/4images/categories.php?cat_id=10 |date=December 7, 2008 }}</ref> to date, main center of Ancient culture in B&H. Daorson in 4th century BC was surrounded by [[megalithic]], {{convert|5|m|ft|adj=mid|-high}} stonewalls (large as those of [[Mycenae]] in [[Greece]]),<ref>[http://www.piramidasunca.ba/en/index.php/DAORSON-CITY-FALSE-INTERPRETATIONS-UP-TO-THE-PRESENT.html Daorson City] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091004112814/http://www.piramidasunca.ba/en/index.php/DAORSON-CITY-FALSE-INTERPRETATIONS-UP-TO-THE-PRESENT.html |date=October 4, 2009 }}</ref> composed out of large trapeze stones blocks. Daors have made their unique bronze coins and sculptures. Finally, [[Roman Empire|Romans]] subdued the Illyrians in first century BC, and after that the history of these parts is history of [[Illyria]]n provinces of [[Roman Empire|Rome]] and [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantium]].
In Bosnia and Herzegovina Romans built several small [[temples]] decorated with [[reliefs]]. The complex of ''step sanctuary in Gradac'' near [[Posušje]] from year 184 AD had [[marble]] temple dedicated to recently deceased emperor [[Marcus Aurelius]]. On the reliefs we can feel [[Naturalism (arts)|naturalism]] of native craftsmen, and in [[mosaics]] the Hellenistic influence, especially in those found in [[villa]]s near [[Stolac]] (second half of the 3rd century). Late Roman art in B&H is marked with building of villas, Christian [[mausoleum]]s, [[basilicas]] and [[oratories]] like: ''Mausoleum in Šipovo'' near [[Jajce]] and ''Villa [[Mogorjelo]]''<ref>[http://www.answers.com/topic/mogorjelo Answers.com]</ref> near [[Čapljina]] (early 4th century). Sculptures that we inherited are ones like: ''Hellenistic relief of Minerva, Jupiter and genius-protector from Šipovo'' (2nd century) and extremely barbarically stylized relief of ''four friends from [[Zenica]]'' (end of the 4th century).<ref>[http://www.zemaljskimuzej.ba/arheologija/antika.php Ancient monuments - National archeological museum in Sarajevo] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090506005533/http://www.zemaljskimuzej.ba/arheologija/antika.php |date=May 6, 2009 }}</ref>
==Medieval art in Bosnia and Herzegovina== [[Image:Stecak iz Radimlje.jpg|thumb|left|<center>[[Stećak]] from Radimlja, 13th century.]] [[Image:Hrvojev misal.jpg|thumb|right|<center>Illumination from [[Hrvoje's Missal]], Split, 1404.]] In Bosnia and Herzegovina the [[Romanesque art|Romanesque]] influence came from [[Croatia]] and it was never accepted in full, only in use of some elements. Those few monuments with Romanesque elements that were preserved are dating from later times. For example: in the motifs from tombstones in Bosnia – natively called [[stećak]] (14th century), or the high parts of ''Tower of [[St. Luke]]'' in [[Jajce]] (15th century).
Influences of [[Gothic art]] in the 14th century are supported by culture of urban cities, [[preaching]] orders, and [[knight]]ly culture. On Bosnian culture there was slight influence of religion and the strong one of Nobility. That is recognizable in the organization of a city that is actually a settlement close to [[feudal]] [[fortress]]. Feudal fortress is of thick roughly cut stonewalls, shape is following the terrain, buildings have steppe roofs and towers are often and high. The most beautiful one is perhaps ''Royal Court in [[Kraljeva Sutjeska]]''; it has [[Gothic architecture|gothic]] [[Portal (architecture)|portals]] and windows, [[buttresses]], and high rooftops (very practical because of snow).
The way some Bosnian nobility treated its dead is somewhat special. From the earliest times of [[Bosnian Kingdom]] the nobility was buried in large necropolises near the roads with graves marked by a monumental tombstone called stećak. [[Stećak]] (or ''mramor'' or ''bilig'') comes in several different shapes and was sometimes engraved with [[reliefs]] showing all sorts of motifs, from figurative to symbols, and sometimes writings in [[Bosnian Cyrillic]]. Their existence is strongly linked with heretical [[Bosnian Church]] and most of the motifs are derived from their beliefs, but some derived from Romanesque (crosses, arcades with semi-circular arches, son, half-moon etc.) and Gothic (arcades with sharp arches, knight riders, shields, swords, lilies etc.) art of the West.
There are two beautiful examples of [[illuminated manuscript]]s from medieval Bosnia. ''Hval’s missionary'', kept in Zagreb, is ravishingly decorated manuscript with many miniatures. ''Misal Hrvoja Vukčića Hrvatinića'' - a [[liturgical book]] of the Bosnian duke and ruler of Dalmatia - [[Hrvoje Vukčić Hrvatinić]], today in [[Istanbul]], is colourfully painted with many details of knightly culture (knights, crests etc.). Both were painted in [[Split (city)|Split]], Croatia.
==Ottoman art in Bosnia and Herzegovina== [[Image:Svrzo house.jpg|thumb|right|''Svrzo house'' in [[Sarajevo]], the typical Bosnian house from Ottoman period.]]
In the 16th century, entire Bosnia was under [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] rule so the influences of renaissance and later baroque from west were extinguished. The only places where some western art could be fined were lonesome [[Franciscan]] monasteries in [[Visoko, Bosnia and Herzegovina|Visoko]], [[Kreševo]], [[Franciscan monastery in Fojnica]], [[Franciscan monastery in Kraljeva Sutjeska]] etc.
However, that opened a new era in B&H art, that of [[Islamic Art]] and it flourished until the 19th century. Actually there were three constant art traditions in B&H living side by side: Catholic-Western one, Orthodox-Byzantine (unique illuminated manuscripts and painted icons) and one and Ottoman-Islamic that was the most powerful one.
Ottomans were developing urban cities very fast upon their conquest of B&H. Enriched by [[Islamic architecture|Islamic]] and [[Byzantine architecture|Byzantine]] experiences they build so much that it can be compared only with medieval building in Dalmatian cities. For example, in [[Foča]] in 16th century Ottomans build 17 [[mosque]]s, 29 public [[fountain]]s, 6 [[public bathing|public baths]] (''hamam'') and 13 caravanserai motels (han). [[Sarajevo]] is an example of a non-urban open city where the most important buildings are organized around one veining street – ''čaršija'' (Persian chahar-su meaning all four sides). In Sarajevo the largest is famous [[Baščaršija]] with shops of 50 different crafts from the 15th century. Also in Baščaršija is most impressive ''Gazi Husrev-beg’s mosque'', also known as ''Beg’s mosque'', built in 1531. Founded on Byzantine central square plan it has dome on large drum, two smaller domes leaning on both sides of drum and a semi-dome behind; in addition, above entrance is a porch with five tiny domes. Inside it is filled with rich wall ornaments in wood and Arabic [[calligraphic]] writings. The complex is complete with a high tower (''munara'') and fountain (''šedrvan'') in the courtyard.
Islamic [[manuscript]]s, decorated in the [[Persian people|Persian]] style with beautiful [[Islamic calligraphy]], were often in B&H so now we have numerous examples in the Bosnian libraries. In the 16th century the [[Jews]] expelled from Spain came to Sarajevo, where they were allowed to settle. Beside important influence on Bosnian culture, they brought with them luxury decorated manuscript called [[Sarajevo Haggadah]] from the 14th century, now in the Sarajevo museum.
The bridge in Islamic art was very important, not only because it request great skill of an architect, but also because of symbolic meaning of a bridge in [[Islam]] where it is a mediator between heaven and earth. That’s why there is no surprise that the high point of [[Islamic architecture]] in B&H is a bridge. Bridge of artisan ''Hajredin'' (pupil of the famous architect [[Mimar Sinan]] from [[Istanbul]]) in [[Mostar]] (so called: [[Stari Most|Old Bridge]]) with its arch over river Neretva is 29 m long and 19.5 m high. With subtle parabola it looks higher and more fragile than it is, an effect seen only in [[Gothic architecture|Gothic cathedrals]].
In Bosnian Islamic architecture, stone is reserved for religious, public buildings and fortifications, while private houses were built out of wood and ''ćerpić'' (native simple bonding material made of clay and straw). With often consol constructions of the upper floors they could be more open with large windows. When the power of Ottomans started to descend in the middle of the 17th century, so did the influence of Islamic art in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
==Art in Austro-Hungarian Period== [[Image:Sarajevo Rathaus05.jpg|thumb|left|National Library in Sarajevo]] [[Image:Sarajevo Academy of arts 02.jpg|thumb|right|The Sarajevo Academy of Arts, on the bank of the [[Miljacka]]]] Right after the [[Austro-Hungarian]] occupation the art scene in Bosnia comes alive. Intense building is represented in modernisation and structural transformation of cities. Architecture is in [[Eclecticism|eclectic]] [[pseudo]] styles like [[classicism]], [[neo-renaissance]], [[neo-baroque]], and even [[neo-Romanesque]], and [[neo-gothic]]. Unique pseudo style is ''“oriental eclectic”'' style (also "[[Pseudo-Moorish style]]") based on [[Islamic architecture#Moorish architecture|Moorish architecture]] of southern [[Spain]] and [[Egypt]]. That style, was quite foreign to urban ambient of Bosnian cities as can be seen in [[Sarajevo]] (National Library and City Hall), [[Mostar Gymnasium]] and [[Travnik]] (Retirement Home).
The first Bosnian artists were educated in large European academies ([[Vienna]], [[München]], [[Prague|Prag]], [[Krakow]], [[Budapest]] and [[Paris]]) thanks to scholarships of cultural societies like “[[Prosvjeta]]” and “[[HKD Napredak|Napredak]]”. All those artists like [[Atanasije Popović]], [[Lazar Draljča|Lazar Drljača]], [[Gabrijel Jurkić]], [[Branko Radulović]], [[Petar Šain]] etc., are marked with [[academism]] with slight touches of [[impressionism]], [[art nouveau]], and [[pointillism]]. After the Great Exhibition of Bosnian Artists in 1917, the native born artists have prevailed. Modern styles that entered B&H were [[expressionism]] and [[Cézanne]]s-ism.
==Art in the Yugoslavian Kingdom== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:MIJIC Mountain landscape.jpg|thumb|right|260 px|"Mountain landscape" by Karlo Mijić, 1924.]] -->After the end of [[World War I]], the society of artists from [[Kingdom of SHS|SHS]] (state of Serbians, Croats and Slovenians) was organized and they held numerous exhibitions and artistic gatherings like ''the Blažuj colony'' of [[Vladimir Becić]]. Participants of that colony were [[Roman Petrović]] and [[Jovan Bijelić]] that derived their art to abstract form (c. 1920), while [[Karlo Mijić]] is devoted to colouristic landscapes. Karlo Mijić, with art nouveau and impressionistic influences was probably the best painter of 20s and 30s in the entire [[Yugoslavia]].
Sadly, the art production in B&H was reduced to crumbs by the Yugoslavian government, so lots of artist never returned to B&H from their studies in [[Zagreb]] and [[Beograd]], while many were also leaving the country. First renewal happened with the ''“Group of Four”'' and ''“engaged art”'' of Roman Petrović and his cycle called ''“The children of the Street”.'' Mijić and ''Đoko Mazalić'' founded the art association called ''“Krug”'' (The Circle) with strong urban aesthetics of nature. [[Vojo Dimitrijević]] painted ''“Spain in ‘37”''; a representative artwork of colouristic expression with traces of Picasso and Chagall.
In thirties the architects were influenced by ideas of [[Functionalism (architecture)|functionalism]], humane architecture and [[Bauhaus]]. Those buildings were uniting a function, content and form, without unnecessary plastic decoration, and with simple rhythm of windows and modern constructions (former ''Social Security Building'' in Mostar by [[Drago Ibler]], 1935.).
==Art in the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia==
Right after [[World War II]], and founding the new country of all south Slavs [[Communist Yugoslavia]], the artist have found new expression through themes of [[Revolution]] and War. Ismet Mujezinović draws numerous expressionistic figures in his cycle ''“The [[Battle of Sutjeska]]”'', and Branko Šotra made powerful almost abstract engravings. Architecture was also under the direct influence of Socialistic architecture, but never reached the monumentality of the original works.
In the fifties, careful and slow, the transformation of art through economy and decoration toward abstraction happened. The first was sculptor ''Mirko Ostoja'' who replaced classical modeling with iron welding. Even the Communist State changed its feeling toward modern art by commissioning large abstract monuments dedicated to famous battles in The War ([[Battle of Sutjeska|Sutjeska]], [[Kozara]], Makljen etc.). Young architects, gathered around professor ''Juraj Neidhardt'', were trying to achieve connections of modern architecture and B&H tradition and surroundings. Those were buildings like The Mostar Mall - ''“Razvitak”'' in 1970 by ''A. Paljaga'' or ''[[Jajce]] Mall'' in 1976 by ''R. Jadrić, Dž. Karić and N. Kurto''.
In the sixties many architects were leaving traditional boundaries and made important buildings in manner of functionalism: The telecommunication building in [[Addis Abeba]] by Ivan Štraus and Zdravko Kovacević, or ''“[[Skenderija]]” Hall'' in Sarajevo by Živorad Janković and Halid Muhasilović<ref>http://stuff.mit.edu/afs/athena/course/4/4.175/OldFiles/www/center_home_sarajevo_contemporary.htm</ref>
In the seventies, the rewarded architectural plans were ''[[Zenica]] Theatre'' in 1977 by ''Jahiel Finci'' and ''Zlatko Ugljen'', ''Hotel Rose'' in Mostar (1979, by Zlatko Ugljen) and ''[[Arena Gripe|Gripe Hall]]'' in [[Split (city)|Split]] (1980, by Živorad Janković and S. Rozić).
An art expression inspired by old Bosnian culture and tradition appeared in the [[graphic]] work of Dževad Hozo and in paintings of ''Mehmed Zaimović, Seid Hasanefendić and [[Mersad Berber]]''. Quite opposite to that, the urban expression of ''Ismar Mujezinović'' is more related to modern film montage and [[photo]]-[[optics]], while [[Braco Dimitrijević]] is a [[Conceptual art]]ist who works mainly outside B&H.
An example of architecture in the eighties is ''[[Holiday Inn]] Hotel'' built in 1983 and the ''“Unis” Twin Towers'' built in [[Sarajevo]] in 1986 and designed by [[Ivan Štraus]]. Among the people of the city, the twin towers are commonly called Momo (Serbian name) and Uzeir (Bosniak name).
==Art after the Bosnian War== [[Image:Sarajevo Twist Tower.jpg|right|thumb|Avaz Twist Tower 2009]] [[Image:SarajevoHolidayInn.JPG|thumb|200px|right|The Holiday Inn, Sarajevo, 1983, architect Ivan Straus. Its distinctive color and location has made the building iconic.]] [[File:Bosmal city center.jpg|right|thumb|Bosmal City Center under construction in 1999]]
Cultural preservation is under way in Bosnia and Herzegovina which can be seen with the most recent reconstruction of Stari most in Mostar and many other structures of cultural and historical significance which were damaged or destroyed in the recent war. Many other projects, unfortunately, are still stifled by political disputes and lack of funds.
Commercial construction in the years following the Bosnian War has seen a boom in Sarajevo. Sarajevo is one of the cities with the most construction in southeastern Europe. ''The Unis Twin Towers'' have been renovated completely. On the site of the former ''Oslobodjenje Towers'', ''the Avaz towers'' have now been constructed. In the ''Hrasno'' residential area, the Bosnian Company Bosmal has constructed the [[Bosmal City Center]], which includes the tallest set of twin towers in the Balkans at 120 meters each.
The [[Avaz Twist Tower]] located in Marijin Dvor, Sarajevo is the tallest tower in Bosnia and Herzegovina. It is the new headquarters for Avaz, the most popular Bosnia and Herzegovina newspaper company.
== See also == * [[Culture of Bosnia and Herzegovina]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== * Malcolm, Noel (1994). BOSNIA A Short History. New York University Press. {{ISBN|0-8147-5520-8}}. * Riedlmayer, Andras (1993). [https://web.archive.org/web/20060618040332/http://www.kakarigi.net/manu/briefhis.htm A Brief History of Bosnia-Herzegovina]. The Bosnian Manuscript Ingathering Project. * ''Umjetničko Blago Bosne i Hercegovine'', several authors, Svjetlost, Sarajevo, 1987.
==External links== * [http://www.muslibegovichouse.com Bosnian National Monument - Muslibegovica House] * [http://www.croatianhistory.net/etf/gjurkic.html Gabrijel Jurkic] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130423055302/http://sarajlijacult.com/ Sarajevo Culture Bureau- a website on contemporary art in Bosnia & Herzegovina]

page.title: Catalogue of Works in Refutation of Methodism

revision.comment: Bot: fix deprecated Citation Style 1 parameters ([[Wikipedia:Bots/Requests for approval/NihlusBOT 9|Task 9]])
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=September 2010}}
{{Infobox book | name = Catalogue of Works in Refutation of Methodism: from its Origin in 1729, to the Present Time | title_orig = | translator = | image = Catalogue of Works in Refutation of Methodism-original 1846 paperback.jpg | caption = A [[photocopyed]] facsimile of a lightly corroded front cover from the original, first paperback edition of ''Catalogue of Works in Refutation of Methodism'', printed in 1846. | author = H.C. Decanver (Curtis H. Cavender) | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = Anti-[[Methodism]] | genre = [[Reference work]] | publisher = John Penington | pub_date = 1846 | english_pub_date = | media_type = Print ([[hardcover]], [[paperback]]) | pages = 54 | isbn = | oclc = 314794301 | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }}
'''''Catalogue of Works in Refutation of Methodism: from its Origin in 1729, to the Present Time'''''<ref name="Catalogue of Works in Refutation of Methodism: Reference 1">{{cite book |last1=Cavender |first1=Curtis H. |authorlink1= |last2= |first2= |editor1-first= |editor1-last= |editor1-link= |others= |title=Catalogue of Works in Refutation of Methodism: from its Origin in 1729, to the Present Time |trans-title=|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UJgsAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=&f=false |format= |accessdate=2 April 2010 |type=Print |edition=1st |series= |volume= |date= |year=1846 |month= |origyear=1846 |publisher=John Penington |location=Philadelphia |isbn= |oclc= 314794301 |doi= |id= |pages=1–2. |ref= |bibcode= |laysummary= |laydate= |separator= |postscript=. |lastauthoramp=}}</ref> (often referred to as '''''Catalogue of Works in Refutation of Methodism''''') is the title of an [[Book collecting#Antiquarian book collecting|antiquarian]] [[bibliography]] or [[wikt:catalogue|catalogue]] first published in America in [[1846 in literature|1846]] <ref name="Catalogue of Works in Refutation of Methodism: Reference 1"/><ref name="Catalogue of Works in Refutation of Methodism: Reference 2">{{cite web |url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/catalogue-of-works-in-refutation-of-methodism-from-its-origin-in-1729-to-the-present-time/oclc/314794301/editions?editionsView=true&referer=di |title=Formats and Editions of ''Catalogue of works in refutation of Methodism'' |first= |last= |author= |authorlink= |coauthors= |date= |month= |year= |work= |publisher=WorldCat.org |location= |page= |pages= |at= |trans-title=|format= |doi= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |accessdate=3 April 2010 |quote= |ref= |separator= |postscript=.}}</ref> by the 19th century author [[Curtis H. Cavender]], who compiled the work under the [[anagrammatic]] [[pen name]] of '''H.C. Decanver'''.<ref name="Catalogue of Works in Refutation of Methodism: Reference 1"/>
A [[reference work]] of [[religious criticism]], the ''Catalogue'' is Decanver's debut publication, and his only written work. It is notable as one of the most prominent writings critical of [[Methodist]] doctrine ever written, and remains the only compilation of books written from a primarily anti-Methodist perspective.
== Background ==
An otherwise virtually unknown individual, the only evidence which suggests that the author Decanver ever existed was the publication of his ''Catalogue'' in 1846. He was self-evidently opposed to the doctrines of [[Methodism]], a branch of [[Protestant Christianity]] which emerged from the teachings of [[John Wesley]] in 18th century England, and in 1846 compiled the catalogue under the full [[title]] of '''''Catalogue of Works in Refutation of Methodism: from its Origin in 1729, to the Present Time: of Those by Methodist Authors on Lay-Representation, Methodist Episcopacy, Etc., Etc., and of the Political Pamphlets Relating to Wesley's "Calm Address to Our American Colonies"'''''.<ref name="Catalogue of Works in Refutation of Methodism: Reference 1"/> The pseudonym "H.C. Decanver" is an anagram of the author's actual name, Curtis H. Cavender.
The book was first published in both hardback and paperback by the presently-defunct [[John Penington (publisher)|John Penington]] publishing company, once located on 10 South Fifth Street in eastern [[Philadelphia]].<ref name="Catalogue of Works in Refutation of Methodism: Reference 3">{{cite web |url=http://www2.hsp.org/collections/manuscripts/p/penington1435.htm |title=Penington Family Papers, The Historical Society of Pennsylvania |first= |last= |author= |authorlink= |coauthors= |date= |month= |year= |work= |publisher=The Historical Society of Pennsylvania |location=Philadelphia |page= |pages= |at= |trans-title=|doi= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |accessdate=3 April 2010 |quote=The eldest of the children of Edward and Sarah Shoemaker Penington, John, devoted his professional life to the literary pursuits his father favored. Born on August 1, 1799, John Penington was the proprietor of a well-known Philadelphia bookshop at '''10 South Fifth Street''', specializing in international trade, rare books, and classical texts both in their original languages and in translation. |ref= |separator= |postscript=.}}</ref> The original printings were attributed to an individual "C. Sherman, printer" from 19 St. James Street in the same city.<ref name="Catalogue of Works in Refutation of Methodism: Reference 1"/>
There are several editions of the book, some including minor changes deviating from former editions.
The catalogue as a whole lists over 100 individual documents, books, pamphlets and articles — many of which today are regarded as historical texts. As a whole the works listed assumedly refute certain doctrines of Methodist thought, although – if somewhat ironically – many of them are by Methodist authors themselves.
== Contents ==
The book is divided into two sections, the first being a [[preface]] entitled either "Prefatory Remarks" or "Preliminary Remarks", depending upon the edition of the book (the first edition of the work was printed containing the latter title), and the second being the catalogue proper – in all editions simply deemed "Catalogue". The Catalogue section is itself divided further, the first group of works representing those called "Anti-Methodistical", the second group listed under "Methodist Authors" (being by Methodist authors themselves), the third called "Miscellaneous", and the last group listed as "Political".
== Further reading ==
* {{cite book |last1=Cavender |first1=Curtis H. |authorlink1= |last2= |first2= |editor1-first= |editor1-last= |editor1-link= |others= |title=Catalogue of Works in Refutation of Methodism: from its Origin in 1729, to the Present Time |trans-title=|url= |format= |accessdate= |type=Print |edition= |series= |volume= |date= |month= |year=1846 |publisher=John Penington |location=Philadelphia |language= |isbn= |oclc= |doi= |id= |page= |pages= |trans-chapter=|chapter= |chapterurl= |quote= |ref= |bibcode= |laysummary= |laydate= |separator= |postscript= |lastauthoramp=}}
== References ==
{{Reflist}}
== External links == * [https://books.google.com/books?id=UJgsAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=catalogue+of+works+in+refutation&hl=en&ei=v-C2S5T4HoP6lweHpImWCg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDsQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=&f=false Full, online, photocopied text of ''Catalogue of Works in Refutation of Methodism '' – formatted from the original hardcover edition (1846)] via [[Google Books]] * [http://www.worldcat.org/search?q=Catalogue+of+Works+in+Refutation+of+Methodism&fq=&dblist=638&start=1&qt=previous_page Search results for 'Catalogue of Works in Refutation of Methodism'] at [[WorldCat]]
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Catalogue Of Works In Refutation Of Methodism}} [[Category:1846 books]] [[Category:American non-fiction books]] [[Category:Christian bibliographies|Methodism]] [[Category:Catalogues]] [[Category:Debut books]] [[Category:Reference works in the public domain]] [[Category:Works published under a pseudonym]]

{{Italic title}} {{Infobox artwork | image_file = Confluence by Stackhouse and Mickett.jpg | painting_alignment = Proper left | image_size = 200px | title = Confluence | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = [[Robert Stackhouse]] & [[Carol Mickett]] | year = {{Start date|2004}} | type = [[Indiana limestone]] | height_metric = | width_metric = | length_metric = | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = in | city = [[Indianapolis, Indiana]], [[United States]] | museum = [[Indianapolis Art Center]] | coordinates = {{coord|39|52|39.33|N|86|8|40.09|W|region:US}} | owner = Indianapolis Art Center }} '''''Confluence''''' is a [[land art]] [[sculpture]] by artists [[Robert Stackhouse]] and [[Carol Mickett]]. The work sits on the grounds of the [[Indianapolis Art Center]] located in [[Indianapolis, Indiana]], [[United States]]. ''Confluence'' was installed as part of the Art Center's ARTSPARK initiative.{{cite web | author=Indianapolis Art Center | year= | title=Indianapolis Art Center Map | work=Artspark | publisher=Indianapolis Art Center | url=http://www.indplsartcenter.org/userfiles/File//ARTSPARK_Map.pdf | accessdate=4 April 2010 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100926223153/http://indplsartcenter.org/userfiles/File//ARTSPARK_Map.pdf | archivedate=26 September 2010 | df= }} ==Description== ''Confluence'' consists of 100 tons of [[Indiana limestone]] cascading in height in a 70-foot [[boat]]-like shape.{{cite web | author= | year=| title=Broad Ripple Village | work=Artspark | publisher=Indianapolis Sports & Travel | url=http://indianapolis-sports-travel.com/broad-ripple-village/ | accessdate= 4 April 2010}}{{cite web | author=Danison, Joy & Sarah Preuschl | year= | title=Stone Souls | work=Cover Gallery | publisher=Indianapolis Woman | url=http://www.indianapoliswoman.com/archive.asp?r=\2004\aug\departments\artsculture\arts-culture1.txt | accessdate= 4 April 2010}}{{cite journal |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |year=2007 |title=Art Attack. |journal=Parks & Recreation |volume=42 |issue=8 |pages=76 |publisher= |doi= |url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=aph&AN=26159470&site=ehost-live |accessdate=5 April 2011 }} The second part of the artwork lies along the White River, further into the ARTSPARK. Words are chiseled into the vertical stones with one statement reading "My soul has grown deep like the rivers." ==Creation== Stackhouse and Mickett created the piece in residency at the Art Center during the summer of 2004.{{cite web | author= | year=2004 | title=Q&A with Dave Thomas | work=Arts | publisher=Nuvo Newsweekly | url=http://www.nuvo.net/gyrobase/qanda-with-dave-thomas/Content?oid=1203992 | accessdate= 4 April 2010}} The installation utilized motorized [[chisel]]s, gas-powered [[saw]]s and hammers to create the columns. Stackhouse oversaw the work on the vertical stones and Mickett handled the arranging of the bases. Visitors to the Art Center were encouraged to participate by being allowed to don goggles, dust masks and gloves to contribute to the creation process. This unique opportunity to participate in the creation process was described by Art Center vice president and programming director David Thomas as being "...such a great chance to connect with people in a meaningful way, to see how an artist like this thinks and works". ==Acquisition== This piece was the first installation acquired for the Art Center's ARTSPARK which, designed by [[Michael Graves]], brings together art and nature. The artwork was a gift from Michael and Mary Ann Browning. ==Information==
''The mission of the Indianapolis Art Center is to engage, enlighten, and inspire our community by providing interactive art education, outreach to underserved audiences, support of artists, and exposure to the visual arts.'' - Indianapolis Art Center Mission Statement{{cite web | author= | year=2010 | title=Mission | work=The Center | publisher=Indianapolis Art Center | url=http://www.indplsartcenter.org/About_Us/The_Center/Mission/ | accessdate=4 April 2010 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110620101658/http://indplsartcenter.org/About_Us/The_Center/Mission/ | archivedate=20 June 2011 | df= }}
Stackhouse and Mickett aimed to create an artwork that integrated "the center's mission, to make it part of its place." ''Confluence'' also seeks to represent journeying, unity and the Art Center's relationship and placement on with the [[White River (Indiana)|White River]]. The words chiseled into the stones tell stories of these subjects with some being inspired by [[Langston Hughes]]' poem "[[The Negro Speaks of Rivers]]." ==References== {{reflist}} {{IACartworks}} [[Category:Land art]] [[Category:Contemporary works of art]] [[Category:Indianapolis Art Center artworks]] [[Category:Limestone sculptures in Indiana]] [[Category:Outdoor sculptures in Indianapolis]] [[Category:2004 sculptures]]

{{distinguish|Dance Research Journal}} {{Unreferenced|date=February 2010}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Use British English|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox journal | title = Dance Research | cover = | discipline = [[Film, Media and Culture Studies]] | website = http://www.euppublishing.com/journal/drs | link1 = http://www.dancebooks.co.uk/sdr-uk/ | link1-name = The Society for Dance Research Homepage | publisher = [[Edinburgh University Press]] | country = [[United Kingdom]] | abbreviation = | history = 1983-present | frequency = Twice-yearly | ISSN = 0264-2875 | eISSN = 1750-0095 }} '''''Dance Research''''' is a twice-yearly [[academic journal]] founded in 1982. It is published by [[Edinburgh University Press]] on behalf of the [[Society for Dance Research]] in Spring and Autumn each year. Each issue contains articles, as well as book reviews and review essays.
== External links ==
* {{Official|http://www.euppublishing.com/journal/drs }}

/* Description */ does it really have the chest of a greyhound and the body of a lion? Those aren't included in the quoted text on this page.
revision.text:
[[File:Kelly Arms OCeallaigR1.jpg|right|thumb|The [[coat of arms]] of the O Kelly of Ui Maine, featuring a green enfield as the [[crest (heraldry)|crest]]]] The '''enfield''' is a fictitious creature sometimes used in [[heraldry]].
==Description== The Enfield has the head of a fox, forelegs like an [[eagle (heraldry)|eagle]]'s talons, {{citation needed span|text=the chest of a [[greyhound]], the body of a [[lion (heraldry)|lion]]|date=May 2018|reason=These two animals are not referenced in text on this page quoted from the same source.}}, and the hindquarters and tail of a [[wolves in heraldry|wolf]].<ref name="ulsterking"/>
==O'Kelly== The earliest known example of the enfield is the [[crest (heraldry)|crest]] of the [[Kelly (surname)|Ó Cellaigh]] clan of Ireland. Ó Cellaigh of [[Uí Maine]] are the most documented O'Kelly sept in early Irish history and annals. The enfield appears in ''[[Leabhar Ua Maine]]''.
The ancient tradition among the O'Kellys is that they have borne this fabulous animal since the days of King [[Tadhg Mór Ua Cellaigh]] who fell "fighting like a wolf dog" on the side of the High King of Ireland, [[Brian Boru]], at the [[Battle of Clontarf]] in 1014. When Tadhg Mor fell this mythical beast issued from the nearby sea to protect the dead body of the chief until it was retrieved for proper burial by his kinsmen.
The animal is sculptured on many old ({{circa|1375}}–1650) tombstones of the O'Kelly family in the Abbey of [[Kilconnell]] (founded ca. 1353 by King [[William Buidhe Ó Cellaigh]]), and in the old church of Cloonkeen.
In 1859, an excavation project found a bronze 15th century O'Kelly seal 20 ft deep in a bog, prompting considerable research on the origins of the O'Kelly enfield on the seal:
{{quote|I have searched in several works on heraldry for a description of the enfield, but without success. It does not appear to be a cognizance of much in use, and it does not appear to be found in [[John Guillim|Gwillam]]'s "Display of Heraldry" folio: not even in Cap 26 of that book, which chapter treats solely of fictitious creatures, supposed to be compounded of different kinds and natures, such as [[Griffon]]s, [[Wivern]]s, [[dragon]]s, [[cockatrice]]s, [[harpy|harpies]], [[mermaid]]s. Neither is the term enfield given or explained in Crossley's "Signification of things borne in Heraldry". To my gifted friend, Sir [[Bernard Burke]], [[Ulster King of Arms]], I, however am indebted for the following definition of this composite fabulous creature, viz. :— "The Enfield is a heraldic animal, having the head of a fox, the breast feathered as an eagle's, the foreclaws also of an eagle; the remainder of the body that of a wolf." It follows from such description that the enfield, being compounded of the fox, eagle, and wolf, indicated that he, by whom it was borne, was reputed to possess the subtlety and cunning of the first named beast; the magnanimity and fortitude, with the honour, labor, industry, and diligence, in great manners, of the eagle; and the fierceness of the wolf.<ref name="ulsterking">''The Journal of the Kilkenny and southeast of Ireland archaeological society'', Vol II, 1858–1859, Dublin, University Press, McGlashan & Gill, p448–449.</ref>}}
==Modern uses== The beast was on the coat of arms of the [[Municipal Borough of Enfield]], which was amalgamated with the [[Municipal Borough of Edmonton]] and the [[Municipal Borough of Southgate]] to form the [[London Borough of Enfield]]. It is unclear whether the beast has any historic connection with the town, but it still makes a striking example of [[canting arms]]. It is used on the modern [[coat of arms of the London Borough of Enfield]] and as an emblem by some organisations there: for example, on the badges of Enfield County School, [[Chace Community School]], Enfield Ignatians R.F.C. and of the football clubs [[Enfield (1893) F.C.]] and [[Enfield Town F.C.]], as well as [[Oneida FC]].
In Australia, it was used in the crest of the former [[City of Enfield]], [[South Australia]] (which was named after the London borough), and is still used by the Enfield Brass Band.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.enfieldbrass.org.au/contact |title=Enfield Brass: Contact |accessdate=24 February 2016}}</ref> It is also used as the centrepiece of the squadron crest of [[No. 38 Squadron RAAF|38 Squadron]] of the Royal Australian Air Force, in [[Queensland]].
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.enfieldsociety.org.uk/links.htm The Enfield Society] *[http://www.ngw.nl/int/gbr/e/enfield.htm International Civic Heraldry]
{{Heraldic creatures}}
[[Category:Heraldic beasts]] [[Category:Mythological hybrids]]

{{Infobox company | name = Facets Multi-Media, Inc. | logo = Facets Multi-Media logo.svg | caption = | type = Private 501(c)(3) organization | genre = | foundation = 1975 | founder = Milos Stehlik | location = 1517 West Fullerton Avenue, Chicago, Illinois, U.S.[http://www.hoovers.com/company-information/cs/company-profile.Facets_Multi-Media_Incorporated.55d2aeabe665fe7b.html Facets Multi-Media Incorporated] from [[Hoover's]] | key_people = Milos Stehlik (Director)[http://www.bbb.org/chicago/business-reviews/video-tapes-and-discs-dealers/facets-multimedia-in-chicago-il-14004464 Facets Multimedia, Inc.] from [[Better Business Bureau]]
Charles Coleman (Programmer)[http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/people-issue-charles-coleman-the-film-adventurist/Content?oid=5199719 Charles Coleman, the celluloid adventurist] from [[Chicago Reader]] | industry = [[Media literacy|Media education]]
[[Movie theater|Independent movie theater]]
[[Video rental]]
[[Home video|Motion-picture video distribution]] | products = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = Facets Cinematheque, Facets Film School, Facets Children's Programs, Chicago International Children's Film Festival, Facets Videotheque, Facets DVD Label | subsid = | homepage = [http://facets.org/ facets.org] | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Facets Multi-Media''' founded in 1975, is a non-profit, [[501(c)#501.28c.29.283.29|501(C)3]] organization, and a leading national media arts organization.https://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/06/us/06cncfacets.html Its mission is to preserve, present, distribute, and educate about film.http://www.facets.org/pages/aboutus.php Besides its facilities at 1517 W. Fullerton Ave., [[Chicago, Illinois]], Facets Multi-Media also runs '''Facets Video''', one of the largest distributors of [[foreign film]] in the United States.http://www.facets.org/pages/exclusives/index.php Facets has been described as a “temple of great cinema”http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/last-tango-in-paris-1972 by film critic [[Roger Ebert]] and "a giant in the rarefied world of art-house films and cultural education." ==Facilities== Facets maintains facilities in Chicago, where it was founded by Milos Stehlik as a [[non-profit]] film organization. The [[Brick and mortar|brick-and-mortar]] space includes a single-screen movie theater (referred to as Facets [[Cinematheque|Cinémathèque]]), which screens "interesting" independent films{{cite web |url=http://chicagoist.com/2013/03/06/chicagoists_favorite_movie_palaces.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-08-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130309024231/http://chicagoist.com/2013/03/06/chicagoists_favorite_movie_palaces.php |archivedate=2013-03-09 |df= }} and "obscure" features not shown anywhere else around Chicago.http://cinematreasures.org/theaters/4506 It also houses a [[video rental|video rental store]] with over 65,000 titles, described as "a stunningly deep archive of every kind of experimental, avant-garde, foreign and children's film you could hope to find."http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/01/15/best-chicago-alternative-_n_2474849.html There is also a non-accredited [[film school]], consisting of classes for the general public. Since the earliest days of home video, customers around the U.S. have been able to rent videos from Facets's "pioneering home-delivery rental system." ==Programs== Facets runs the annual [[Chicago International Children's Film Festival]], a [http://www.cicff.org/content/facets-kids-film-camp/81 Kids Film Camp] for ages 7–14, [http://www.facets.org/pages/filmschool.php Facets Film School] for Chicago-area cinephiles, [http://www.facets.org/pages/nightschool.php Facets Night School] for cult film connoisseurs, and a [http://facets.org/filminstitute Summer Film Institute] for K-12 teachers.http://www.edweek.org/ew/articles/2013/08/15/01film.h33.html ==Facets Video== Facets is a nationally-recognized conservator, publisher and distributor of films on DVD, including [[Independent film|independent]], [[Art house|art-house]], [[Classical Hollywood cinema|classics]], [[Documentary film|documentaries]], and [[experimental film]]s.{{cite web |url=http://chicagoist.com/2011/07/14/we_say_send_those_netflix_dollars_t.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-08-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140911050148/http://chicagoist.com/2011/07/14/we_say_send_those_netflix_dollars_t.php |archivedate=2014-09-11 |df= }} Facets has distributed films by renowned directors such as [[Bela Tarr]], [[Jean-Luc Godard]], [[Miloš Forman]], [[Věra Chytilová]], [[Amos Gitai]], [[Alexander Kluge]], [[Andrzej Żuławski|Andrzej Zulawski]], and [[Miklós Jancsó]]. Notable films released by Facets include ''[[Dekalog]]'', ''[[Heimat (film series)|Heimat]]'', ''[[Satantango]]'', ''[[Medea (1988 film)|Medea]]'', ''[[Hamlet (1964 film)|Hamlet]]'', ''[[Germany in Autumn]]'', ''[[La Bataille du rail|La Bataille du Rail]]'', ''[[Germany, Pale Mother]]'', ''[[Valerie and Her Week of Wonders (film)|Valerie and Her Week of Wonders]]'', ''[[The Steamroller and the Violin]]'', ''[[Christ Stopped at Eboli (film)|Christ Stopped at Eboli]]'', ''[[Walking, Walking|Keep Walking]]'', ''[[Love (1971 film)|Love]]'', ''[[The Joke (film)|The Joke]]'', ''[[Three Wishes for Cinderella]]'', ''[[Three Brothers (1981 film)|Three Brothers]]'', ''[[Total Balalaika Show]]'', ''[[The House Is Black]]'', ''[[The Fifth Horseman is Fear|The Fifth Horseman Is Fear]]'', ''[[Voyage in Time]]'', and ''[[The Murder of Fred Hampton]]''. Since the late 1980s, Facets has released over 800 films on VHS and DVD. == References == {{reflist|2}} == External links == * {{official website|1=http://www.facets.org}} [[Category:Film archives]] [[Category:Film organizations in the United States]] [[Category:Cinemas and movie theaters in Chicago]] [[Category:Film distributors of the United States]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1975]] [[Category:1975 establishments in Illinois]]
